Absent the element of “lascivious intent,” the statute is constitutionally overbroad.

It does not discuss standards for modification of custody or parenting time under M.G.L. c. 208, § 28, nor does it address what constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances affecting a child’s best interests. *Cooper v. Keto*, 83 Mass. App. Ct. 798.relevant_excerpt: "Here, we again witness another puzzling situation in which the legal fees paid and awarded far exceed any amount that would be gained. Indeed, the father has acknowledged that the costs associated with defending the action might better have been spent on the child’s college education. Litigation should be the last option, not the first. To that end, it is often beneficial to the parties, and counsel in advising their clients, to step back and take stock of what the case is about, what has gone on before, and what may lie ahead."

McDonald is a paternity/relocation case under G.L. c. 209C focused on a sole legal custodian’s right to relocate prior to an adjudication of paternity. It does not discuss post‑judgment modification standards, ‘material and substantial change in circumstances,’ or the modification framework under G.L. c. 208, § 28. Citing Smith v. McDonald as authority for the proposition that a material and substantial change since a 2019 judgment warrants modification of custody and parenting time under § 28 is therefore inaccurate; the case is about statutory interpretation of the paternity statute and removal, not modification standards.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.relevant_excerpt: “This matter begins and ends with statutory interpretation. The paternity statute, which governs here… makes unmistakably clear that the mother is the sole legal parent of a nonmarital child from the moment of the child’s birth until the establishment of the putative father as a legal parent… Here, the critical and determining fact… is that the mother… moved to New York with the child at a time when, as the child’s only legal parent, she was free to do so without the court’s or the putative father’s permission… This is not a removal case, and Yannas is inapposite.”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: “Under Massachusetts law, '[m]odification of a custody order is appropriate when the moving party demonstrates a material and substantial change in circumstances and that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child.' *Cooper v. Keto*, 83 Mass. App. Ct. at 804; see also *Schuh v. Schuh*, 453 Mass. at 815–816; *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 262–263 (2001).”
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the statutory and common-law standard for modifying a prior custody judgment: there must be a material and substantial change in circumstances and the modification must be in the child’s best interests. The court then applies that standard to hold that a change in custody was improper because no such change in circumstances was shown. This aligns with and supports the proposition for which Rosenthal is cited.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 182\u.proposition: A parenting schedule that requires an 8‑year‑old child to wake at approximately 4:30 a.m. on school mornings on a recurring basis is inherently destabilizing and contrary to the child’s physical and educational welfare, and the Court has authority to modify the schedule to avoid such harm. See, e.g., *Cooper v. Keto*, 83 Mass. App. Ct. at 804–805 (modification proper where parenting plan no longer serves child’s interests); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 182–183 (2006) (recognizing court’s broad discretion to structure parenting time to promote child’s welfare).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 182\u.support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case involving joint physical custody. It discusses the best‑interests standard and the court’s discretion in evaluating relocation, but it does not address parenting schedules, early wake‑up times, or any inherent destabilizing effect of such schedules. While it generally recognizes the court’s authority to structure custody and parenting arrangements in the child’s best interests, it does not provide specific authority for the proposition about a 4:30 a.m. school‑morning schedule being inherently harmful or modifiable on that basis.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 182\u.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ … Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion. … Where physical custody is shared, a judge’s willingness to elevate one parent’s interest in relocating freely with the children is often diminished.”

R.D. v. A.H., 454 Mass. 706, 710\u201371.proposition: Where the parties are unmarried parents, similar authority is granted under M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20, permitting modification of custody and visitation orders 'as the best interests of the child require.' See *R.D. v. A.H.*, 454 Mass. 706, 710–711 (2009).
R.D. v. A.H., 454 Mass. 706, 710\u201371.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns M.G.L. c. 209C, § 20 and the standard for modifying custody and visitation orders for unmarried parents. This opinion discusses c. 209C only in the context of § 10, interprets who qualifies as a “parent,” and explains when a nonparent may obtain custody; it does not mention § 20 or modification authority under that section. Accordingly, it cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition that § 20 grants modification power based on the best interests of the child in cases of unmarried parents.
R.D. v. A.H., 454 Mass. 706, 710\u201371.relevant_excerpt: “Nor is R.D. aided by her reliance on G. L. c. 209C, § 10… In light of this construction of the word, R.D. is not correct that G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), applies to someone in her position, that is, a person who is not a biological parent. It is § 10 (d), rather than § 10 (a), that is potentially applicable to R.D., because she is ‘a person who is not a parent of the child [who] requests custody.’”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: Changes in a parent’s residence and the resulting impact on the child’s routine and welfare are properly considered in determining whether a material change has occurred and whether modification is warranted. See *Schuh v. Schuh*, 453 Mass. at 815–816; *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 710–712 (1985) (relocation analysis emphasizing child’s interests); *Cooper v. Keto*, 83 Mass. App. Ct. at 804–805.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: Yannas is a removal/relocation case decided in the context of an original divorce and custody judgment, not a postjudgment modification case requiring a threshold showing of “material change in circumstances.” The opinion develops the ‘real advantage’ and best‑interests framework for assessing relocation, focusing on how a move affects the child’s quality of life, relationships, and needs, but it does not discuss material change or standards for modifying an existing custody order. Thus it supports relocation analysis emphasizing the child’s interests, but not the specific proposition about material change for modification.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”
